dialogue.text: (Detective Elias Wakefield steps out of a carriage, adjusting his gloves as he gazes at the grand Blackwood estate. The night air hums with the distant chatter of high society, and warm candlelight spills from the ballroom windows.)
It's cold.
(A security guard blocks the entrance.)
(You know... on second thoughts, I don't think I'm in the mood for a party at the moment)
(Elias hops back on to the carriage, deciding to spend his night at a nearby teahouse instead, fully in bliss)
Go right in, Sir Wakefield.
(Elias steps inside, greeted by an older man in a suit)
Good evening, Sir Elias. I am Alistair Henshaw, let me lead you to the ballroom while our maid Edith here brings your luggage to your room.
Thank you.
(The ballroom is lively, filled with guests in elegant attire.)
Ah, Detective Wakefield, welcome! I trust your journey was pleasant?
As pleasant as one can expect. I am honored by the invitation, my lord.
Ah, let me introduce you to my business associates
(Blackwood then leads Elias to a group of chattering people)
Excuse me, everyone, sorry to interrupt, this is my good pal, and also the best detective in town, Elias Wakefield.
Haha, I wouldn't call myself the best...
Ah yes, I've heard of you, Sir Wakefield. I'm Henry Fairfax, nice to meet you.
It's a pleasure to meet you, Sir. I'm Rosalind
(Among the group, a woman in a green dress stays silent, her eyes averted, seeming to be deep in thought)
Eleanor? You look unwell--
I've been overworking myself. Excuse me, I need a drink.
(Eleanor leaves, still looking distressed. Blackwood was speechless for a moment)
Ahem, I deeply apologize for that, Detective. That was my sister, Eleanor. This behavior is very unlike her at all.
No worries, my lord. It's fine.
(The atmosphere then quiets down, turning awkward as each person sips their drink)
(Then a new guest arrives, taking away everyone's attention)
(A stunning woman in a red gown enters. Blackwood immediately rushes to greet her.)
Oh my, her dress must be worth thousands.
Blackwood still has the soul of a young bachelor, even at his age.
Drinks, Sir Wakefield?
Yes, thank you
(Elias picks up a champagne glass, then moves to a quieter corner, observing Eleanor's continued unease.)
